thread.title: Lasorda: Utley went ‘out of his way’ to take out Tejada
thread.title_full: Lasorda: Utley went ‘out of his way’ to take out Tejada | New York Post

author: Priscilla DeGregory
title: Lasorda: Utley went ‘out of his way’ to take out Tejada
text:
Even Hall of Fame former Dodgers manager Tommy Lasorda thinks Chase Utley went “out of his way” to take out Ruben Tejada, leaving the Mets shortstop with a broken leg . 
Lasorda, at the team’s New York base, the Palace Hotel, said Utley had no intentions of injuring Tejada during Game 2 of the National League Division Series in Los Angeles on Saturday but also admitted the Dodgers pinch hitter was aiming for the well off the base Tejada.
“Personally I hate to see someone get hurt like that. It’s a tough play for him it’s very, very hard,” Lasorda told The Post. “But I don’t think he was trying to hurt him.”
But the former Brooklyn Dodgers hurler added: “He [Utley] seemed like he was trying to break up the double play and that’s what his intentions were but it looked like he had to go out of his way to get him.”
Lasorda managed the Dodgers from the end of 1976 through midseason in 1996.
He was at the helm when Los Angeles last won an NL pennant — beating the Mets — and World Series title, way back in 1988.
Ruben Tejada is upended by Chase Utley in Game 2 of the NLDS. Photo: Getty Images Lasorda called or new rules to better protect middle infielders, who are targets of hard-sliding baserunners.
MLB, before last season, outlawed runners from running over catchers at home plate.
“You know what I’ve been saying? They give catchers protection, right?” Lasorda said. “What about those middle infielders? What kind of protection do you want to give them?”
He declined to question MLB’s move to suspend Utley .
“You’re asking the wrong guy. I don’t second guess people,” he said. “They do the best they can I guess and it’s not going to impress everybody. Some may like it some may not like it.”
